questions.article:
The following text is adapted from John Matheus’s 1926 short story Mr. Bradford Teaches Sunday School. Mr. Bradford is driving through the countryside in Florida.

The moss in the towering water oaks had become enlivened with a verdant sheen of silver and hung like festoons of carnival or like funeral decorations for the mourning of the dead. The pine green was resplendent. The bald cypresses spread themselves along the water courses while the willows wept as they always did. Mr. Bradford was conscious for this gorgeous display of nature.
questions.question: As used in the text, what does the word “display” most nearly mean?

options.name: A
options.content: Spectacle

options.name: B
options.content: Reproduction

options.name: C
options.content: Pretentiousness

options.name: D
options.content: Disguise

questions.correct: Spectacle

questions.article: Belane Mocsary, who traveled solo to four continents in the early 1900s, undoubtedly accomplished much, but her place in our historical memory is perhaps more ______ than that of a noteworthy “first” such as Adeline and Augusta Van Buren, who were the first women to ride solo motorcycles across the continental United States, a deed for which they will always be remembered.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: enduring

options.name: B
options.content: conspicuous

options.name: C
options.content: deserving

options.name: D
options.content: uncertain

questions.correct: uncertain

questions.article: A number of recording artists ______ distinctions between Indigenous music and other musical styles. For example, Inuit singer-songwriter Tanya Tagaq incorporated Inuit throat singing into electric music on her album Tongues, and Swinomish/Inupiaq musician Black Belt Eagle Scout combined powwow-style melodies with rock on her album At the Party with My Brown Friends.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: disguise

options.name: B
options.content: reject

options.name: C
options.content: replace

options.name: D
options.content: observe

questions.correct: reject

questions.article: Text corpora such as the British National Corpus are enormous collections of electronically stored texts that can be used for empirical testing of hypotheses regarding how ______ a word is in spoken and written English. For instance, one might have a guess about the incidence of the word “world,” but only an analysis of a corpus can prove that “world” is the eighth most commonly used noun.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: pervasive

options.name: B
options.content: credible

options.name: C
options.content: assertive

options.name: D
options.content: profound

questions.correct: pervasive

questions.article: ______ though it seems to many mathematicians, Nagata’s conjecture, posed in 1972, eventually yielded to the combined efforts of Ualbai U. Umirbaev and Ivan P. Shestakov, who presented a proof of it in 2004.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: Unequivocal

options.name: B
options.content: Ineluctable

options.name: C
options.content: Irreproachable

options.name: D
options.content: Insuperable

questions.correct: Insuperable

questions.article: Mexican textile artist Victoria Villasana weaves stories of triumph, using her unique method of applying colorful yarn to photographs of people. In some works, Villasana focuses on celebrating cultural icons who are people of color, as she does in her depiction of activist Ryu Gwansun. However, in other works, Villasana honors ordinary people, as she does in her captivating portrayal of a young girl sitting on a sidewalk. Villasana sees both of these approaches as ways of depicting the power and interconnectedness of all people.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.name: A
options.content: To emphasize that Villasana prefers to focus on famous figures in her work.

options.name: B
options.content: To offer an overview of Villasana’s artistic style.

options.name: C
options.content: To demonstrate that Villasana collaborates frequently with other artists.

options.name: D
options.content: To provide an example of an everyday individual that Villasana portrayed in her work.

questions.correct: To provide an example of an everyday individual that Villasana portrayed in her work.

questions.article:
Text 1
For decades ornithologists assumed that if they saw a singing Bell’s vireo—a bird species found in temperate North America—they must be observing a male. That’s because birdsong has long been considered a male trait; researchers have argued that singing enables males to attract mates and claim territory.

Text 2
Recent evidence shows that a female Bell’s vireo is as capable of song as a male is. In fact, Kara J. Odom and colleagues found evidence of female song in 71% of the 323 species they examined. They claim that the historical mischaracterization of birdsong as a male trait is largely the result of bias: much of the research ornithologists have carried out has been near universities in the temperate northern hemisphere, where female birdsong is less common than it is in the tropics.
questions.question: Based on the texts, how would Odom and colleagues (Text 2) most likely respond to the view of birdsong presented in Text 1?

options.name: A
options.content: They would suggest that it reflected a tendency to study male birds rather than female birds.

options.name: B
options.content: They would claim that other factors than mate attraction and territorial defense have driven the evolution of singing in male birds.

options.name: C
options.content: They would underscore that male songbirds in temperate zones are likely using their songs for different purposes than are male songbirds in the tropics.

options.name: D
options.content: They would argue that it was influenced by the kinds of study sites researchers tended to select.

questions.correct: They would argue that it was influenced by the kinds of study sites researchers tended to select.

questions.article: Like all species of baleen whales, the sei whale feeds on tiny creatures known as krill by filtering water through bristlelike keratin structures called baleen plates. In this way, baleen whales can eat up to 30 percent of their total mass per day. And while no one would call the sei whale small—it can have a mass as high as 25,000 kg—it is one of the smaller baleen whales and is much smaller than the northern right whale, which can weigh a whopping 80,000 kg and consume as much as 24,000 kg krill per day.
questions.question: Based on the text, what can most reasonably be concluded about krill consumption among sei and northern right whales?

options.name: A
options.content: The northern right whale is able to eat more krill per day than the sei whale is.

options.name: B
options.content: Both the sei whale and the northern right whale can eat as much as 24,000 kg of krill per day.

options.name: C
options.content: The quantities of krill consumed by northern right whales has made it difficult for sei whales to find sufficient food.

options.name: D
options.content: Most baleen whales include krill in their diets, but the sei whale is less likely than the northern right whale to do so.

questions.correct: The northern right whale is able to eat more krill per day than the sei whale is.

questions.article: Wenheng Zhang and colleagues have explored how convergent evolution—a phenomenon that occurs when the same trait evolves independently in two reproductively separate lineages—can result from a genetic mechanism shared by both lineages. Meanwhile, Armin P. Moczek and colleagues have investigated how convergence occur through different genetic mechanisms, but the relative prevalence of convergence through shared and different genetic processes is still poorly understood. This motivated biologists Delber A. Green II and Cassandra G. Extavour to evaluate both types of convergence in a single study for their 2012 paper.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: Before Green and Extavour’s study, convergent evolution was assumed to require a shared genetic mechanism between two lineages that share the trait.

options.name: B
options.content: Green and Extavour’s study was conducted using data from the studies by Zhang and colleagues and Moczek and colleagues.

options.name: C
options.content: Green and Extavour’s study addresses convergent evolution more comprehensively than the studies by Zhang and colleagues and Moczek and colleagues do.

options.name: D
options.content: Both the study by Zhang and colleagues and that by Green and Extavour compare convergence through shared genetic mechanism to convergence through different genetic mechanisms.

questions.correct: Green and Extavour’s study addresses convergent evolution more comprehensively than the studies by Zhang and colleagues and Moczek and colleagues do.

questions.article:
US Hydroelectric Power Plants, 2019

A run-of-river hydroelectric power plant, as the name suggests, uses the natural flow of a water source to generate electricity but is unable to start or stop that flow through its generators. In contrast, a peaking hydroelectric power plant (used when demand for electricity peaks) controls the flow of water through its generators: starting flow when demand is high enough, stopping it when demand is too low, and otherwise regulating it to keep pace with changing electricity needs. Although peaking plants do not typically operate continuously as run-of-river plants do, peaking plants can generate more megawatt hours of power per year (MWh/yr) than some run-of-river plants. For example, the ______
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the table to complete the example?

options.name: A
options.content: average power generated annually by the J. Woodruff plant is higher than that generated by any of the run-of-river plants in the table.

options.name: B
options.content: J. Woodruff plant, which is a peaking plant, has more generators than any of the other plant in the table.

options.name: C
options.content: average power generated annually by the Norway plant is higher than that generated by the Superior Falls plant.

options.name: D
options.content: run-of-river plant with the highest average annual power generation in the table generated more electricity than the peaking plant with the highest annual power generation in the table.

questions.correct: average power generated annually by the J. Woodruff plant is higher than that generated by any of the run-of-river plants in the table.

questions.article: It is common for freshwater lakes near or above a latitude of 45o north of the equator, like Lake Mjosa in Norway, to accumulate surface ice in winter. The amount and duration of ice depends on many factors, including local weather conditions as well as the lake’s depth, volume, and surface area, but a climate researcher claims that some lakes in these latitudes have seen a decline in the duration of ice between the early 1980s and the mid-2000s.
questions.question: Which choice best describes data in the table that support the researcher’s claim?

options.name: A
options.content: Kalmarinjarvi had fewer days of ice in the winter of 2005-06 than it did in the winter of 1980-81.

options.name: B
options.content: Kalmarinjarvi is at a higher latitude than Mirror Lake and typically had fewer days of ice per winter than Mirror Lake did.

options.name: C
options.content: Kalmarinjarvi is at a higher latitude than Mirror Lake and typically had more days of ice per winter than Mirror Lake did.

options.name: D
options.content: Lake Neusiedl had more days of ice in the winter of 2005-06 than it had in the winter of 1980-81.

questions.correct: Kalmarinjarvi had fewer days of ice in the winter of 2005-06 than it did in the winter of 1980-81.

questions.article: Many pastes contain copper oxide nanoparticles (CuO-NPs) which can leach into waterways and soils via wastewater. In a 2012 study, Superb K. Misra and colleagues found that CuO-NPs can accumulate in the bodies of great pond snails (Lymnaea stagnalis). While bioaccumulation of manufactured nanoparticles may be inherently worrisome, it has been hypothesized that CuO-NP bioaccumulation in invertebrates like L. stagnalis could serve a valuable proxy role, obviating the need for manufacturers to conduct costly and intrusive sampling of vertebrate species—such as African clawed frogs (Xenopus laevis), commonly used in regulatory compliance testing—for nanoparticle bioaccumulation, as environmental protection laws currently require.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly weaken the hypothesis presented in the text?

options.name: A
options.content: When L. stagnalis and X. laevis are exposed to similar levels of CuO-NPs, concentrations of CuO-NPs in animals of both species show little variation from individual to individual.

options.name: B
options.content: The rate of CuO-NP uptake in L. stagnalis differs from the rate of CuO-NP uptake in X. laevis in a way that is not yet well understood by researchers.

options.name: C
options.content: L. stagnalis has been shown to accumulate several other types of manufactured nanoparticles in addition to CuO-NPs, whereas X. laevis has been shown to accumulate only CuO-NPs.

options.name: D
options.content: Compared with X. laevis, L. stagnalis can accumulate detectable CuO-NP concentrations with significantly fewer negative effects.

questions.correct: The rate of CuO-NP uptake in L. stagnalis differs from the rate of CuO-NP uptake in X. laevis in a way that is not yet well understood by researchers.

questions.article: Callie W. Babbitt, Hema Madaka, and colleagues assembled a database of materials used in consumer electronics by studying products in the lab and by gathering data from similar product studies. The team gave each of these studies a rating for level of traceability (with a higher rating for clearer descriptions of procedures) and for category consistency (with a higher rating for using materials categories more closely aligned with the categories in the team's database). Based on these ratings, a second research team concluded that the methodology was better explained in a study by Lutz Stobbe than it was in a study by Martin Streicher-Porte and colleagues.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly challenge the second research team’s conclusion?

options.name: A
options.content: The study by Stobbe had a lower traceability than the study by Streicher-Porte and colleagues did.

options.name: B
options.content: The study by Stobbe had a high consistency rating and a high traceability rating.

options.name: C
options.content: The study by Stobbe had a lower consistency rating than the study by Streicher-Porte and colleagues did.

options.name: D
options.content: The study by Streicher-Porte and colleagues had a medium consistency rating and a medium traceability rating.

questions.correct: The study by Stobbe had a lower traceability than the study by Streicher-Porte and colleagues did.

questions.article: Arthurian legends (tales related to the character of King Arthur) derive from many often contradictory sources, such as Preiddeu Annwfn, composed around 900, and Perceval, the Story of the Grail from around 1181. Sir Thomas Malory's 15th-century text Le Morte d'Arthur was an attempt to compile these stories into a coherent narrative. Many of Malory's sources derive from Geoffrey of Monmouth's History of the Kings of Britain, written in the 1130s. While neither History nor any works that predate it mention Arthur's famous Round Table at which his knights assembled, Le Morte d'Arthur does, suggesting that ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: Geoffrey of Monmouth's accounts of Arthurian legends in History are more similar overall in content to the accounts in Perceval, the Story of the Grail than they are to the accounts in Le Morte d'Arthur.

options.name: B
options.content: Malory encountered the Round Table in a source that Geoffrey of Monmouth was not familiar with when writing his History.

options.name: C
options.content: Le Morte d'Arthur is more historically accurate than History, because Perceval, the Story of the Grail had not been written when Geoffrey of Monmouth was writing his work.

options.name: D
options.content: when a version of an Arthurian legend contradicted the version in History, Malory preferred to include Geoffrey of Monmouth’s version in Le Morte d'Arthur.

questions.correct: Malory encountered the Round Table in a source that Geoffrey of Monmouth was not familiar with when writing his History.

questions.article: In June of 1987, South Korea liberalized its stock market, meaning that it began allowing foreign individuals and businesses to invest money in South Korean companies. This was part of a wave of stock market liberalizations from the mid-1980s through the mid-1990s—Brazil in 1988, Venezuela in 1990, and so on. In an analysis of economic data from 1976 to 1993, Ross Levine and Sara Zervos found that liberalization did not lead to enduring increases in investment in companies based in countries that liberalized. Peter Blair Henry, however, found that, on average, investment in companies in liberalized countries increased significantly in the three years following liberalization. Taken together, these results suggest that ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: investment growth is likely to be more consistent in countries that liberalize than in countries that do not.

options.name: B
options.content: it typically takes at least three years for companies to benefit from government policies allowing foreign investment, but governments rarely maintain such policies for that long.

options.name: C
options.content: economists' expectations about the effect of liberalization on investment were largely correct.

options.name: D
options.content: companies based in countries that begin allowing foreign investment will probably see short-term increases in investment but that these gains are unlikely to last.

questions.correct: companies based in countries that begin allowing foreign investment will probably see short-term increases in investment but that these gains are unlikely to last.

questions.article: Each year, the Nobel Prize in Literature is given to an author who has, in the words of its founder Alfred Nobel, “produced the most outstanding work in an idealistic ______ in 1952, for instance, judges recognized François Mauriac “for the deep spiritual insight and the artistic intensity with which he has in his novels penetrated the drama of human life.”
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: direction” and,

options.name: B
options.content: direction”

options.name: C
options.content: direction,”

options.name: D
options.content: direction”;

questions.correct: direction”;

questions.article: In Los Angeles County, California, bicycle paths such as the San Gabriel River bicycle path—which is 28 miles long—have become an increasingly popular means of travel. Moreover, lawyer and cycling ______ has identified several features of the Los Angeles landscape, like its temperate climate and mostly flat roads, that make the city naturally bike-friendly.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: advocate Ernesto Hernandez-Lopez,

options.name: B
options.content: advocate, Ernesto Hernandez-Lopez,

options.name: C
options.content: advocate Ernesto Hernandez-Lopez

options.name: D
options.content: advocate, Ernesto Hernandez-Lopez

questions.correct: advocate Ernesto Hernandez-Lopez

questions.article: Yerevan is the capital city of Armenia and, ______ roughly one million people, home to an impressive 36 percent of Armenia's total population.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: contained

options.name: B
options.content: contains

options.name: C
options.content: containing

options.name: D
options.content: has contained

questions.correct: containing

questions.article: It was the kind of challenge that would set any art curator's mind into ______ that elusive thread that could link artists as disparate as American abstract painter Anne Ryan, Romanian impressionist painter Micaela Eleutheriade, and Flemish mannerist painter Anthony van Dyck.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: motion, finding:

options.name: B
options.content: motion. Finding

options.name: C
options.content: motion; finding

options.name: D
options.content: motion: finding

questions.correct: motion: finding

questions.article: In 2020, internationally renowned Slovak photographer Máriá Svarbvá exhibited her work at the Contessa Gallery and the Art Angle Gallery in the United States and ______ utilizing vivid pastel colors, overexposed tones, and mirrorlike symmetry, Svarbová’s photographs evoke a Socialist-era aesthetic that she describes as “minimalistic but also futuristic.”
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: Japan, respectively,

options.name: B
options.content: Japan, respectively;

options.name: C
options.content: Japan; respectively,

options.name: D
options.content: Japan, respectively

questions.correct: Japan, respectively;

questions.article: Though he’s performed on many respected albums, including Trypnotyx by Victor Wooten, drummer Dennis Chambers may be best known for his time as house drummer for the hip-hop label Sugar Hill Records. He did not play drums on the label’s classic song “Rapper’s ______ he joined the label after the song’s release.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: Delight,” however,

options.name: B
options.content: Delight,” however;

options.name: C
options.content: Delight.” However,

options.name: D
options.content: Delight” however

questions.correct: Delight,” however;

questions.article: With their distinctive cone shapes and steeply sloping sides, the volcanoes Mangarei (New Zealand) and Harunasan (Japan) may look similar from afar. Tehnuka Ilanko and other volcanologists, ______ can tell by how each was formed that Maungarei is a cinder cone volcano, while Harunasan is a composite volcano.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: in addition,

options.name: B
options.content: therefore,

options.name: C
options.content: for example,

options.name: D
options.content: though,

questions.correct: though,

questions.article: Space scientist Maggie Aderin-Pocock is excited about the potential of the new James Webb Space Telescope (JWST). Unlike its predecessor the Hubble Telescope, the JWST is optimized for infrared wavelength. When light from distant galaxies is infrared, ______ the JWST can provide sharp images that reveal much more information about those galaxies than the Hubble could.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: consequently,

options.name: B
options.content: admittedly,

options.name: C
options.content: actually,

options.name: D
options.content: in addition,

questions.correct: consequently,

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Antonio Stradivari (1644-1737) made about 1,000 violins in his lifetime.
  • Musicians prize his Stradivarius violins for their famed sound quality.
  • Many of the 500 or so that exist today are named for a previous owner.
  • The Jules Falk Stradivarius is named for Jules Falk, an American violinist.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to explain how the Jules Falk Stradivarius got its name?

options.name: A
options.content: Jules Falk was an American violinist.

options.name: B
options.content: Of the 1,000 or so violins Antonio Stradivari made, only about 5000 exist today.

options.name: C
options.content: Designed by Antonio Stradivari. Stradivarius violins like the Jules Falk are renowned for their quality.

options.name: D
options.content: The Jules Falk Stradivarius is named after its former owner, Jules Falk.

questions.correct: The Jules Falk Stradivarius is named after its former owner, Jules Falk.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Grimanesa Amoros is a Peruvian American artist.
  • She is well known for her large-scale LED light sculptures.
  • Argentum debuted in 2018 at the Bronx Museum of the Arts in New York City, New York.
  • It is made of iridescent multicolored LED domes.
  • It occupies 253 cubic feet of space.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to emphasize when and where Argentum debuted?

options.name: A
options.content: As is common of Grimanesa Amoros’s sculptures, the iridescent multicolored LED domes of Argentum cut and imposing 253 cubic foot figure when the piece debuted.

options.name: B
options.content: Artist Grimanesa Amoros often works with light in her sculptures, which tend to be large in scale.

options.name: C
options.content: In 2018, Grimanesa Amoros debuted Argentum in New York City, New York.

options.name: D
options.content: Grimanesa Amoros is a Peruvian American artist who often works with LED light in her large scale sculptures, such as Argentum [2018].

questions.correct: In 2018, Grimanesa Amoros debuted Argentum in New York City, New York.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Calida Garcia Rawles is an African American painter.
  • She is known for her large scale, hyperrealistic paintings depicting African American figures in water.
  • The painting Lightness of Being (24*30in) depicts a young man with his arms outstretched floating on the right side of the canvas.
  • Lost in the Shuffle (36*24in) depicts two young men with their arms outstretched floating in the bottom left and upper right corners of the canvas.
  • She paints the water with vivid blue colors, including sky blue and indigo.
  • The mood in the painting is calm.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to emphasize the location of the figures in Lost in the Shuffle?

options.name: A
options.content: At 36 by 24 inches, Rawles’s Lost in the Shuffle is even larger than the sizable 24-by 30-inch painting Lightness of Being.

options.name: B
options.content: Rawles captures the water in paintings such as Lightness of Being and Lost in the Shuffle in vivid hues of sky blue and indigo.

options.name: C
options.content: In Rawles’s painting Lost in the Shuffle, two young men are depicted in the bottom left and upper right corners of the canvas.

options.name: D
options.content: While the number of figures may differ, constant among Rawles’s hyperrealistic works is the calm mood that paintings evoke.

questions.correct: In Rawles’s painting Lost in the Shuffle, two young men are depicted in the bottom left and upper right corners of the canvas.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Ynés Mexía was a Mexican American botanist.
  • Between 1917 and 1938, she collected over 150,000 botanical samples throughout the Americas.
  • She collected a sample of Trixis antimenorrhoea in Minas Gerais, Brazil, on June 26, 1930.
  • She collected a sample of Stephanomeria thurberi in Chihuahua, Mexico, on May 27, 1929.
  • These specimens are members of the Asteraceae family.
  • They can now be viewed online at the C. V. Starr Virtual Herbarium.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to emphasize when she collected both of the samples?

options.name: A
options.content: Thousands of botanical samples collected by Ynés Mexía can now be found in one place: online at the C. V. Starr Virtual Herbarium.

options.name: B
options.content: While both specimens collected by Ynés Mexía are members of the same family, Trixis antimenorrhoea was found in Minas Gerais and Stephanomeria thurberi was found in Chihuahua.

options.name: C
options.content: On June 26 in 1930, Ynés Mexía added a new specimen to her growing collection of botanical samples: Trixis antimenorrhoea of the Asteraceae family.

options.name: D
options.content: Ynés Mexía collected a sample of Trixis antimenorrhoea in June of 1930, after collecting Stephanomeria thurberi in May of 1929.

questions.correct: Ynés Mexía collected a sample of Trixis antimenorrhoea in June of 1930, after collecting Stephanomeria thurberi in May of 1929.
